title: Thailand 'more competitive'
text:
NEWSPAPER SECTION: LIFE | WRITER: KARNJANA KARNJANATAWE - + According to the latest report from the World Economic Forum, Thailand's travel & tourism competitiveness ranking has moved up to being 35th in the world, up from its position of 43rd two years before. 
Tourists at Maya bay, Krabi. 
The biennial report titled "Travel & Tourism Competitiveness Index 2015" analyses the performance of 141 countries based on 14 factors such as safety and security, price competitiveness, environmental sustainability, tourist service infrastructure, natural and cultural resources. 
The report identifies how the world's most competitive country is Spain, followed by France, Germany, US, UK, Switzerland, Australia, Italy, Japan and Canada. 
For Southeast Asia, Singapore leads the group and ranks 11th in the global index, followed by Malaysia (25th), Thailand (35th), Indonesia (50th), the Philippines (74th), Vietnam (75th), Laos (96th), Cambodia (105th) and Myanmar (134th). 
The top factor that has helped Thailand be more competitive is its tourist service infrastructure, which in the report covers the numbers of hotel rooms, ATM or credit card acceptance and satisfied business travellers. The second factor is price competitiveness, followed by the quality of the labour force, the prioritisation of travel and tourism, especially from government policy, and health and hygiene. 
Meanwhile the factor that the Kingdom achieves the lowest score is in cultural resources and business travel, measured by the total numbers of international association meetings, world heritage sites, large sports stadiums and cultural expressions. 
The next factor is ground and port infrastructure, with the country getting poor rates for railroad density, quality of railroad infrastructure and ground transport network. 
Improvement was needed in care for environmental sustainability, international openness covering visa requirements and safety and security. Tourism sustainability on the agenda 
The Pacific Asia Travel Association (Pata) has signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) to promote tourism sustainability, especially along coastal areas in the Asia-Pacific region. 
"This new partnership will allow us to share information with Pata member companies, to explore business risks and opportunities within the tourism industry, and to create new solutions together," said IUCN regional director for Asia Aban Marker Kabraji. 
By having access to the IUCN's knowledge and best practices, it will enable Pata's members to make smarter decisions in the context of environment and conservation, said Pata CEO Mario Hardy. Airlines update VietJet has signed a contract with Universal Pictures and Illumination Entertainment to depict the small yellow cartoon characters of Minions, the Despicable Me movie spin-off. 
The creatures will appear on one of its brand-new Airbus planes. 
According to the airline, the Minions will bring smiles to passengers coming on-board VietJet flights this summer. The airline will also arrange mascots to greet passengers and offer gifts on some occasions. 
In addition, it will launch a promotion to give away round-trip tickets for lucky passengers through its microsite at www.minions.vietjetair.com from tomorrow to July 30. 
VietJet has 25 Airbus A320 and A321 aircrafts flying 150 flights a day to 30 destinations within Vietnam as well as to Thailand, Singapore, Korea, Taiwan, Cambodia and China. Visit www.vietjetair.com for more details. Japan Airlines has added new Western languages to its travel information section. 
Called "Guide to Japan", the information will be available in French, German and Russian in addition to the existing languages of English and Chinese. 
The Guide to Japan features where to go, what to do and how to dine as well as events and recommended spots. Visit www.jal.com for more details. Hotels update Manathai Hotels & Resort officially opened its hotel in Koh Samui last week. 
Called Manathai Koh Samui, the beachfront hotel is located on Lamai beach, about 20 minutes from Samui international airport. 
It offers 148 rooms and suites with space usage starting from 32m² to 200m², three food outlets, a pub, fitness, kids' club, two swimming pools, free Wi-Fi and two meeting rooms which can accommodate up to 60 guests. Visit www.manathai.com/samui for more details. AccorHotels has joined hands with other sponsors to support the Pilgreens project. 
The project is initiated by three master's degree students, one German and two French, of the University of Toulouse in France. They plan to drive an electric tuk tuk equipped with two electric batteries and a solar panel from Bangkok to their university located at the heart of southwestern France. 
The aim is to raise awareness of green energy transportation in developing countries. The team chose Bangkok as the starting point because they also studied the double-degree programme at the University of Toulouse Graduate School of Management and the College of Management of Mahidol University. 
The 20,000km tuk tuk journey will span 120 days from July to November and across 16 countries. 
During the journey, the team will stay and park their bright green tuk tuk at AccorHotels. They will also meet with other fellow students, business and government leaders as well as non-governmental organisations to promote green energy and produce a video documentary to raise awareness for this campaign.
